steps.text: Become certified in Food Manufacturing, Processing and Storage Pest Control - Classification 7.
Pass the general standards exam.
Study materials in 'A Guide for Private and Commercial Applicators: Applying Pesticides Correctly'.
Pass the exam based on this manual and Arkansas Pest Control Law.
Obtain study materials from the Arkansas State Plant Board.
Acknowledge sources of additional information.
Check pesticide information for currency.
Ensure intended use aligns with product label.
Integrate chemical, physical, cultural, and biological controls for pest management in food processing facilities.
Use pesticides as a last resort.
Construct a well-built building.
Implement preventive design and maintenance.
Implement daily pest management programs for food plants.
Maintain records as part of the program.
Address pests from facility, surrounding areas, and incoming materials.
Stay informed of federal and state regulations.
Maintain short grass and trim shrubs.
Pave access areas.
Ensure proper drainage.
Place an 18- to 24-inch strip of gravel around the foundation.
Position night-lights at least 30 feet away from doors.
Maintain a minimum distance of 4 inches between framing and walls.
Fill any necessary voids with materials such as polyurethane foam.
Coat concrete floors for improved sanitation.
Use acid-proof or brick floors in wet processing areas.
Seal wall materials like concrete, brick, or tile.
Easy to clean wall materials.
Seal hollow panel-type walls.
Check that roofs are smooth and free of standing water.
Inspect pitch and gravel or corrugated metal roofs for insect harboring.
Use few windows with transparent glass.
Choose metal tight-fitting doors.
Install air curtains at large doors.
Install dust-tight fixtures for good lighting.
Provide electrical and plumbing services for easy access and cleaning.
Control panels should be insect-proof.
Equipment should be roomy and accessible for cleaning.
Equipment should be raised at least six inches off the floor or sealed to it.
Perform preventive maintenance.
Eliminate litter, waste, and uncut grass.
Maintain grounds by preventing litter, waste, and uncut grass.
Pave dusty roads.
Maintain lawns.
Ensure proper drainage.
Position lighting away from buildings.
Reduce bird harborage.
Reduce outside food spillage.
Use rodent, insect, and bird traps.
Maintain housekeeping.
Implement pest monitoring programs (e.g., pheromone traps).
Maintain bait stations for rodents.
Use insecticidal baits and approved insecticides near breeding sites.
Use chemical repellents and avicides where appropriate.
Rodent-proof all openings on buildings.
Screen windows.
Eliminate cracks, crevices, and ledges.
Block bird access to ledges.
Locate equipment off the floor or sealed to it.
Keep all areas free of loose materials (Nonchemical Management).
Clean structures and equipment.
Use electrified grids for insect attraction inside.
Inspect all incoming vehicles and materials.
Store materials away from walls for inspection access.
Use rodent traps near doors.
Map the locations of the rodent traps.
Use air curtains at doors.
Use deterrents for birds on roosting sites.
Use rodent bait stations where policy permits.
Use space treatments with nonresiduals.
Use crack and crevice treatments with residuals.
Apply spot treatments.
Perform fumigation for raw commodities.
Implement a detailed monitoring program.
Establish a total facility IPM program.
Use rodent traps near doors.
Ensure proper sanitation.
Use space treatments in pesticide management.
Use spot treatments in pesticide management.
Use crack and crevice treatments in pesticide management.
Use contact treatments in pesticide management.
Treat packaging areas.
Use appropriate treatments in packaging areas as finished foods are exposed.
Identify potential sources of pests in packaging materials.
Implement pest management procedures for packaging materials.
Implement effective pest management programs in finished products warehouse.
Maintain the finished products warehouse.
Ensure vehicles are clean and free of infestation.
Inspect and prepare carriers (boxcars, trucks) for loading.
Treat spaces before loading.
Create an in-plant sanitation program.
Form an inspection committee with the highest company official as chairman and include all department heads.
Next step in the process.
Review existing activities.
Compile a list of deficiencies.
The committee should wear identifiable uniforms.
Carry necessary tools: flashlights and scrapers.
Thoroughly inspect new places.
Do not just focus on areas with a history of problems.
Record all defects completely and specifically.
Distribute notes to department heads.
Take action on recorded defects.
Departments should correct defects immediately.
Committee meets to review notes and assign correction dates.
Sanitation is the responsibility of everyone in the plant.
Look in obscure places using a flashlight.
Observe suspect stock by spreading it on a flat surface.
Inspect areas most likely to produce results.
Examine equipment from the opposite side.
Suspect any unaccounted-for voids in equipment or structures.
Observe employee actions and in-plant practices.
Reward good sanitation to encourage plant-wide cooperation.
Consider periodic inspections by an outside firm.
Require an 18-inch space between pallets and walls in the Warehouse for inspections.
Write an inspection procedure for incoming raw products.
Follow the written procedure to inspect incoming raw products.
Accept vehicles according to guidelines.
Record problems on a form.
Maintain housekeeping standards.
Implement pallet-cleaning program.
Follow stock storage specifications.
Use a reliable stock rotation method.
Quickly remove spills and trash.
Emphasize systematic approach to commodity protection.
Integrate control measures: natural enemies, cultural management, temperature, sanitation, and pesticides.
Determine if potential losses exceed economic threshold.
If so, proceed with the action.
Regulate postharvest systems based on moisture content.
Determine appropriate moisture level for specific pests.
Most processed goods are low in moisture.
Maintain low moisture to reduce pest development.
Identify temperature as the most important factor.
Identify unfavorable temperature range for insects and molds.
Determine the action when temperatures fall below or exceed this range.
Maintain good sanitation.
Control temperature to slow pest growth.
Minimize movement of stored product insects.
Prevent insects from flying.
Carefully inspect all incoming materials.
Design buildings to minimize entry points.
Use visual inspection as a key method.

Look for open packages and signs of poor sanitation.

Add food attractants to the traps.

Place one trap per 4,000-5,000 square feet.
Focus on high-risk areas.
Examine trends in trap catches over time.
Modify management practices based on findings.
Use pheromone-baited traps in a warehouse.
Place the traps effectively.
Inspect bagged commodities.
Identify pests.
Determine the extent of a problem.
Evaluate a treatment method.
Identify the pest species.
Determine attraction of pests to pheromone traps based on their lifespan.

Identify common insect pests in processed food.
Match the trap type to the environment.
Use pitfall traps or traps that deflect dust in dusty areas.
Adapt trap placement to changing temperature gradients.
Place traps on the outer perimeter of a facility.
Determine number of traps based on quality assurance standards and goal.
Begin with a wide grid (one trap per 100,000 cubic feet).
If pests are detected, move traps or add more to the suspect area.
Visually search areas where the most insects were captured.
Look for increases in numbers from one period to the next when interpreting catches.
Set up pheromone traps.
Place glue boards.
Conduct visual inspections for insects, rodents, and birds.

Carry out the specified structural modifications.
Maintain cold storage at 50°F.
Provide proper lighting placement.

Perform routine fumigation.

Install netting for bird control.

Inspect for presence of other insect species.

Ensure use is consistent with labeling.
Identify the type of food-handling establishment and the food being processed.
Identify non-food areas.
Identify food areas.
Apply residual treatment to broad surfaces such as walls and floors.
Limit application to nonfood areas.
Apply insecticide to limited areas where insects are likely to occur but will not contact food or workers.
Apply small amounts of insecticide into cracks, crevices, expansion joints, and voids.
Arkansas State Plant Board regulates pesticide applications.
Use a pesticide on a food product only if it has a tolerance or is exempt.
EPA sets tolerances under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FFDCA) and the Food Quality and Protection Act (FQPA) of 1996.
The FDA enforces tolerances for food and feed.
The USDA enforces tolerances for meat.
Identify if food product contains unapproved pesticide or residue above tolerance level.
Destroy the adulterated food product.
Check if the application site is listed on the pesticide label.
Apply the pesticide only to sites listed on its label.
Obtain USDA-approved list of pesticides for federally inspected meat plants.
Use only pesticides from the approved list in USDA Meat Plants.
Residuals cannot be used in production areas where the product is exposed.
Residuals can be used as a crack and crevice treatment if the opening is sealed after application.
Conduct a survey of the facility.
Consider potential interactions with the facility's practices.
Identify life stages of beetles and moths: egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
Determine current stage for effective control methods.
Identify the type of larva: moth or beetle.
Determine if the larva has legs on its back half.
Adult beetles have chewing mouthparts and feed on food products.
Adult moths have sucking mouthparts and do not feed on solid food but can contaminate products.
Identify Almond Moth.
Examine forewings for brown-gray color.
Inspect larvae for dirty white color.
Identify the Indianmeal Moth as a common stored product pest.
Locate sources of infestation such as dried fruits, nuts, pet foods, and candies.
Identify the forewings' color pattern.
Determine the larvae's webbing behavior.
Spin silken threads to web food particles together.
Prefer flour for food.
Identify the color and pattern of Mealmoth's forewings.
Describe the appearance of Mealmoth's larvae.
Inspect incoming goods for damp or spoiled grain.
Remove infested food and dust.
Heat treat the grain at 140°F for one hour.
Apply cold treatment.
Use residual insecticides.
Apply space sprays.
Perform fumigation.
Identify Lesser Grain Borer as a small, cylindrical, dark brown beetle.
Inspect grains for damage caused by the beetles or their larvae.
Identify the presence of a small, oval, reddish-brown beetle with a humped appearance.
Identify the type of beetle present as Drugstore Beetle.
Determine the feeding habits of Drugstore Beetles: they consume dry organic substances.
Identify Confused and Red Flour Beetles.
Identify the type of beetle.
Determine if the beetle can fly.
Identify Merchant Grain Beetle.
Inspect food of vegetable origin for presence.

Check for signs of mold or mildew.

Check for activity in dark, damp areas.

Examine the beetles for variable patterns and prominent bristles on their larvae.
Check for cockroach infestation by looking for their cast larval skins.

Determine they are general feeders.

Determine their gradual metamorphosis (egg, nymph, adult).
Identify signs of infestation such as cast skins, egg cases, and musty odor.

Identify the type of cockroach based on color and location.
Determine preferred habitats for each identified species.
Identify the type of cockroach: Oriental Cockroach.
Locate areas preferred by Oriental Cockroaches: dark, damp areas such as crawl spaces and drains.

Locate the cockroaches in areas such as high walls, ceilings, and appliances.

Compare to old droppings.
Determine if droppings are dull and hard.

Search for greasy runways indoors.

Pay attention to doors, windows, vents, drainpipes, foundations, and utility lines.
Place toxic dust in runways.
Cannot be used near food.

Identify preferred food types for different rodent species.
Select appropriate bait based on rodent preference and availability of food sources.
Offer unpoisoned bait for several days to overcome shyness.
Place bait in tamper-proof stations.

Place stations every 20 feet for rats.

Place traps along walls, in dark corners, and behind objects.
Use multiple traps, placing them close together.

Never leave pressurized when unattended.

Keep Space Treating Equipment dry.
Measure droplet size in microns.
Determine if aerosol is gas-propelled or thermally released.
Obtain a can or container of the substance.
Use for flushing, space treatments, or crack and crevice applications.

Settle out more rapidly.
Use Ultra Low Dosage (ULD) method.

Use filters for particulates.
